question: What is Infoblox and its core functions?
answer:
Infoblox is a DDI (DNS, DHCP, IPAM) solution providing centralized network services management.

Core functions: 1) DNS - authoritative and recursive, 2) DHCP - IP address assignment, 3) IPAM - IP address management, 4) Network Insight - discovery and visibility.

Key features: 1) Centralized management, 2) High availability, 3) API automation, 4) Reporting and analytics, 5) Security integration.

Deployment options: 1) Physical appliances, 2) Virtual appliances, 3) Cloud (BloxOne), 4) Hybrid deployments.

question: Explain Infoblox Grid architecture.
answer:
The Infoblox Grid provides distributed DDI services with centralized management.

Grid components: 1) Grid Master - central management, 2) Grid Members - service delivery, 3) Grid Master Candidate - HA backup.

Grid types: 1) Single Grid Master, 2) HA Grid Master pair, 3) Multi-Grid with Cloud Network Automation.

Communication: 1) Encrypted grid communication, 2) VPN for remote members, 3) Port 2114 for grid traffic.

Benefits: 1) Single pane of glass, 2) Automatic synchronization, 3) Distributed services, 4) Centralized reporting.

question: What is IPAM and how does Infoblox implement it?
answer:
IPAM (IP Address Management) tracks and manages IP address allocation across the network.

IPAM features: 1) Network discovery, 2) IP allocation tracking, 3) Conflict detection, 4) Utilization reporting, 5) Historical data.

Infoblox IPAM objects: 1) Network containers, 2) Networks, 3) IP ranges, 4) Fixed addresses, 5) Host records.

Automation: 1) Next available IP, 2) Next available network, 3) DHCP integration, 4) API provisioning.

Reporting: 1) Utilization reports, 2) Audit trails, 3) Conflict detection, 4) Capacity planning.

question: Explain Infoblox DNS configuration.
answer:
Infoblox provides both authoritative and recursive DNS services.

DNS types: 1) Authoritative - hosts zone data, 2) Recursive - resolves queries, 3) Forwarders - delegates queries.

DNS objects: 1) DNS views - namespace separation, 2) Zones - domain containers, 3) Resource records - A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, etc.

DNS views: 1) Internal view, 2) External view, 3) Match clients - IP-based selection, 4) Split-brain DNS.

Advanced features: 1) DNSSEC, 2) Response Policy Zones (RPZ), 3) DNS traffic control, 4) Anycast.

question: What are DNS record types supported by Infoblox?
answer:
Infoblox supports all standard DNS record types plus custom extensions.

Common records: 1) A - IPv4 address, 2) AAAA - IPv6 address, 3) CNAME - canonical name, 4) MX - mail exchange, 5) NS - name server.

Service records: 1) SRV - service location, 2) TXT - text data, 3) PTR - reverse lookup.

Advanced records: 1) CAA - certificate authority, 2) NAPTR - naming authority, 3) TLSA - TLS authentication.

Infoblox specific: 1) Host record - A + PTR combined, 2) Shared record groups, 3) Extensible attributes.

question: Explain Infoblox DHCP configuration.
answer:
Infoblox DHCP provides centralized IP address assignment and management.

DHCP objects: 1) Networks, 2) Ranges, 3) Fixed addresses, 4) Reservations, 5) Options.

DHCP options: 1) Option 3 - default gateway, 2) Option 6 - DNS servers, 3) Option 15 - domain name, 4) Option 66/67 - TFTP boot.

Advanced features: 1) Failover - HA between members, 2) Option 82 - relay agent info, 3) Filters - MAC-based policies, 4) Lease times.

Integration: 1) Automatic DNS updates, 2) IPAM synchronization, 3) Fixed address from host record.

question: What is DHCP Option 82 and how does Infoblox use it?
answer:
Option 82 (Relay Agent Information) provides additional context about DHCP requests.

Option 82 sub-options: 1) Circuit ID - port/VLAN info, 2) Remote ID - switch identifier, 3) Vendor-specific info.

Use cases: 1) IP assignment based on switch port, 2) VLAN-based addressing, 3) Location tracking, 4) Security policies.

Infoblox configuration: 1) Enable Option 82 processing, 2) Create filters matching Option 82, 3) Assign ranges or fixed IPs, 4) Logging and reporting.

Security benefits: 1) Prevent rogue DHCP, 2) Port-based access control, 3) Audit trail, 4) Network access compliance.

question: Explain Infoblox extensible attributes.
answer:
Extensible attributes add custom metadata to Infoblox objects for organization and automation.

Attribute types: 1) String, 2) Integer, 3) List, 4) Email, 5) Date.

Use cases: 1) Asset tagging, 2) Location tracking, 3) Owner assignment, 4) Automation triggers.

Inheritance: 1) Network to IP inheritance, 2) Zone to record inheritance, 3) Override at any level.

Reporting: 1) Filter by attributes, 2) Search across objects, 3) API queries, 4) Custom reports.

question: What is Infoblox Network Insight?
answer:
Network Insight provides network discovery and device tracking capabilities.

Discovery methods: 1) SNMP discovery, 2) CLI discovery, 3) NetBIOS, 4) DNS-based.

Discovered data: 1) Network devices, 2) Switch ports, 3) MAC addresses, 4) IP addresses, 5) VLANs.

Use cases: 1) Rogue device detection, 2) Asset inventory, 3) Port utilization, 4) IP reconciliation.

Integration: 1) IPAM correlation, 2) Automatic updates, 3) Conflict detection, 4) Historical tracking.

question: Explain Infoblox high availability configurations.
answer:
Infoblox HA ensures continuous DDI services through redundancy.

HA options: 1) Grid Master HA pair, 2) DHCP failover, 3) DNS secondary, 4) Anycast.

Grid Master HA: 1) Active/passive pair, 2) Automatic failover, 3) Virtual IP (VIP), 4) Database replication.

DHCP failover: 1) Load balancing mode, 2) Failover mode, 3) State synchronization, 4) Split scope.

DNS HA: 1) Primary/secondary zones, 2) Zone transfers, 3) Anycast for recursive, 4) Geographic distribution.

question: What is Infoblox API (WAPI)?
answer:
WAPI (Web API) enables programmatic access to Infoblox for automation.

API features: 1) RESTful interface, 2) JSON/XML responses, 3) CRUD operations, 4) Bulk operations.

Common operations: 1) Create records, 2) Search objects, 3) Modify attributes, 4) Delete objects.

Authentication: 1) Basic auth, 2) Certificate auth, 3) API user accounts.

Use cases: 1) Provisioning automation, 2) CI/CD integration, 3) Self-service portals, 4) CMDB sync.

question: Explain Infoblox DNS Security (Threat Intelligence).
answer:
Infoblox provides DNS-based security through threat intelligence integration.

Security features: 1) Response Policy Zones (RPZ), 2) Threat feeds, 3) DNS tunneling detection, 4) Data exfiltration prevention.

RPZ actions: 1) NXDOMAIN - block, 2) NODATA - empty response, 3) Redirect - safe page, 4) Passthru - allow.

Threat intelligence: 1) Infoblox threat feeds, 2) Third-party feeds, 3) Custom blacklists, 4) Real-time updates.

Reporting: 1) Blocked query logs, 2) Threat reports, 3) Trend analysis, 4) Security dashboards.

question: What is Infoblox DNSSEC?
answer:
DNSSEC provides DNS response authentication and integrity verification.

DNSSEC components: 1) Zone signing - adds signatures, 2) Key management - KSK/ZSK, 3) Chain of trust - DS records, 4) Validation - verify signatures.

Key types: 1) KSK - Key Signing Key, 2) ZSK - Zone Signing Key, 3) DS - Delegation Signer.

Infoblox DNSSEC: 1) Automatic signing, 2) Key rollover, 3) HSM integration, 4) Validation.

Deployment: 1) Sign authoritative zones, 2) Enable validation on recursive, 3) DS record at parent, 4) Monitor key lifecycle.

question: Explain Infoblox smart folders and saved searches.
answer:
Smart folders and saved searches organize and filter Infoblox data.

Smart folders: 1) Dynamic grouping, 2) Based on criteria, 3) Auto-updating, 4) Hierarchical organization.

Saved searches: 1) Store search criteria, 2) Quick access, 3) Share with users, 4) Export results.

Search capabilities: 1) Global search, 2) Object-specific, 3) Extensible attributes, 4) Regular expressions.

Use cases: 1) Network organization, 2) Quick reporting, 3) Audit assistance, 4) Team workflows.

question: What is Infoblox reporting and how to use it?
answer:
Infoblox provides comprehensive reporting for DDI operations and analytics.

Report types: 1) DNS reports, 2) DHCP reports, 3) IPAM reports, 4) Audit reports, 5) Security reports.

Common reports: 1) DHCP utilization, 2) DNS query volume, 3) Top talkers, 4) Lease history, 5) Configuration changes.

Scheduling: 1) On-demand, 2) Scheduled, 3) Email delivery, 4) Multiple formats.

Customization: 1) Filter criteria, 2) Time ranges, 3) Object scope, 4) Custom columns.

question: Explain Infoblox admin roles and permissions.
answer:
Role-based access control restricts Infoblox operations based on user roles.

Built-in roles: 1) Superuser - full access, 2) Admin Group - administrative, 3) Read-only - view only, 4) Custom roles.

Permission types: 1) Object permissions, 2) Function permissions, 3) Network permissions, 4) Global permissions.

Role assignment: 1) Local users, 2) LDAP/AD groups, 3) RADIUS authentication, 4) Admin groups.

Best practices: 1) Least privilege, 2) Group-based assignment, 3) Audit permissions, 4) Separate duties.

question: What is Infoblox backup and recovery?
answer:
Backup and recovery procedures protect Infoblox configuration and data.

Backup types: 1) Database backup, 2) Full backup (with logs), 3) Scheduled backups, 4) One-click backup.

Backup destinations: 1) TFTP, 2) FTP, 3) SCP, 4) Grid file distribution.

Recovery scenarios: 1) Member recovery, 2) Grid Master recovery, 3) Database restore, 4) Disaster recovery.

Best practices: 1) Regular scheduled backups, 2) Off-site storage, 3) Test restores, 4) Document procedures.

question: Explain Infoblox DHCP fingerprinting.
answer:
DHCP fingerprinting identifies device types based on DHCP request characteristics.

Fingerprint data: 1) Option ordering, 2) Requested options, 3) Vendor class, 4) Parameter request list.

Use cases: 1) Device identification, 2) Policy enforcement, 3) Network visibility, 4) Security compliance.

Infoblox features: 1) Built-in fingerprint database, 2) Automatic updates, 3) Custom fingerprints, 4) API access.

Integration: 1) IPAM device tracking, 2) Reporting, 3) Filters and policies, 4) Security events.

question: What is Infoblox cloud integration (BloxOne)?
answer:
BloxOne extends Infoblox DDI and security services to cloud and hybrid environments.

BloxOne services: 1) DDI - cloud DNS/DHCP/IPAM, 2) Threat Defense - DNS security, 3) Cloud Network Automation.

Deployment: 1) SaaS platform, 2) On-premises connectors, 3) Cloud connectors (AWS, Azure, GCP).

Features: 1) Hybrid DNS, 2) Cloud IPAM, 3) DNS security, 4) Centralized management.

Integration: 1) On-prem Grid sync, 2) Cloud provider APIs, 3) Automation platforms, 4) Security ecosystem.

question: Explain Infoblox troubleshooting tools.
answer:
Infoblox provides tools for diagnosing DNS, DHCP, and network issues.

Diagnostic tools: 1) DNS lookup, 2) Dig utility, 3) Ping, 4) Traceroute, 5) Port test.

Log analysis: 1) Syslog, 2) DNS query logs, 3) DHCP lease logs, 4) Audit logs.

Debug options: 1) DNS debug, 2) DHCP debug, 3) Grid communication, 4) Capture traffic.

Common issues: 1) DNS resolution failures, 2) DHCP not assigning IPs, 3) Grid sync problems, 4) Performance issues.

question: What is Infoblox DNS traffic control?
answer:
DNS traffic control provides intelligent DNS responses for global load balancing.

Traffic control features: 1) GSLB - global load balancing, 2) Health monitoring, 3) Topology-based steering, 4) Ratio-based distribution.

Pool types: 1) A record pool, 2) CNAME pool, 3) NAPTR pool.

Load balancing methods: 1) Round robin, 2) Ratio, 3) Topology, 4) Source IP hash.

Monitoring: 1) HTTP/HTTPS monitors, 2) TCP monitors, 3) ICMP monitors, 4) Custom monitors.

question: Explain Infoblox IPv6 support.
answer:
Infoblox provides comprehensive IPv6 DDI capabilities.

IPv6 features: 1) DHCPv6, 2) AAAA records, 3) IPv6 networks in IPAM, 4) Dual-stack support.

DHCPv6 modes: 1) Stateful - full address assignment, 2) Stateless - options only (SLAAC), 3) Prefix delegation.

IPAM considerations: 1) /64 standard allocation, 2) Subnet hierarchy, 3) Address planning, 4) Utilization tracking.

Transition: 1) Dual-stack management, 2) DNS64/NAT64 support, 3) IPv4/IPv6 correlation.

question: What is Infoblox upgrade process?
answer:
Infoblox upgrades require careful planning and execution.

Upgrade planning: 1) Review release notes, 2) Check compatibility, 3) Backup configuration, 4) Schedule maintenance window.

Upgrade order: 1) Grid Master Candidate first, 2) Then Grid Master, 3) Finally members.

Upgrade methods: 1) GUI upgrade, 2) CLI upgrade, 3) Scheduled upgrade.

Post-upgrade: 1) Verify services, 2) Check grid status, 3) Test functionality, 4) Monitor performance.

question: Explain Infoblox SNMP monitoring.
answer:
SNMP enables external monitoring of Infoblox appliances.

SNMP versions: 1) SNMPv1, 2) SNMPv2c, 3) SNMPv3 (recommended).

Monitored metrics: 1) System health, 2) Service status, 3) Query rates, 4) DHCP utilization.

Trap notifications: 1) Service state changes, 2) HA events, 3) Resource alerts, 4) Security events.

Integration: 1) SolarWinds, 2) Nagios, 3) PRTG, 4) Custom NMS.

question: What is Infoblox CSV import/export?
answer:
CSV import/export enables bulk data management in Infoblox.

Supported operations: 1) Import new objects, 2) Export existing data, 3) Bulk updates, 4) Data migration.

Common imports: 1) Networks, 2) Host records, 3) Fixed addresses, 4) Zones.

Import process: 1) Download template, 2) Populate data, 3) Validate file, 4) Import and verify.

Best practices: 1) Start with export template, 2) Validate before import, 3) Test in lab, 4) Backup before bulk changes.

question: Explain Infoblox DNS views and split-brain DNS.
answer:
DNS views provide different responses based on client source.

View configuration: 1) Create multiple views, 2) Define match clients, 3) Add zones to views, 4) Order views properly.

Split-brain DNS: 1) Internal view - private IPs, 2) External view - public IPs, 3) Same zone name, different data.

Match criteria: 1) Source IP/network, 2) TSIG key, 3) Any combination.

Use cases: 1) Internal vs external resolution, 2) Department-specific DNS, 3) Testing environments.

question: What is Infoblox lease scavenging?
answer:
Lease scavenging removes stale DHCP and DNS records automatically.

Scavenging targets: 1) Expired leases, 2) Abandoned records, 3) Orphaned DNS records, 4) Stale fixed addresses.

Configuration: 1) Enable scavenging, 2) Set thresholds, 3) Schedule intervals, 4) Define scope.

Benefits: 1) Clean database, 2) Accurate IPAM, 3) Reduced conflicts, 4) Better performance.

Considerations: 1) Don't scavenge too aggressively, 2) Test settings, 3) Monitor results, 4) Exclude critical records.

question: Explain Infoblox Microsoft integration.
answer:
Infoblox integrates with Microsoft infrastructure for unified DDI management.

Integration options: 1) MS DNS synchronization, 2) AD authentication, 3) Azure DNS, 4) DHCP migration.

MS DNS sync: 1) Import zones from MS DNS, 2) Manage in Infoblox, 3) Sync changes back.

AD integration: 1) LDAP authentication, 2) Group-based permissions, 3) User provisioning.

Use cases: 1) Gradual migration from MS DNS, 2) Centralized management, 3) Enhanced security.

question: What is Infoblox Network Automation?
answer:
Network Automation enables infrastructure-as-code for DDI management.

Automation tools: 1) Ansible modules, 2) Terraform provider, 3) REST API, 4) Python SDK.

Common workflows: 1) Provision networks, 2) Create DNS records, 3) Assign IPs, 4) Configure DHCP.

CI/CD integration: 1) Git-based configs, 2) Pipeline automation, 3) Testing and validation, 4) Rollback capabilities.

Benefits: 1) Consistent deployments, 2) Version control, 3) Reduced errors, 4) Self-service.

question: Explain Infoblox best practices for enterprise deployment.
answer:
Best practices ensure reliable, scalable Infoblox deployments.

Architecture: 1) HA Grid Master, 2) Distributed members, 3) Anycast for DNS, 4) Regional deployment.

Security: 1) RBAC configuration, 2) Audit logging, 3) Encrypted communications, 4) Regular updates.

Operations: 1) Regular backups, 2) Monitoring and alerting, 3) Capacity planning, 4) Change management.

Integration: 1) CMDB sync, 2) Automation platforms, 3) Security tools, 4) Monitoring systems.
